review.title: Is There a Role for Qualitative Risk Assessment?
review.abstract: Classically, risk is characterized by a point value probability indicating the likelihood of occurrence of an adverse effect. However, there are domains where the attainability of objective numerical risk characterizations is increasingly being questioned. This paper reviews the arguments in favour of extending classical techniques of risk assessment to incorporate meaningful qualitative and weak quantitative risk characterizations. A technique in which linguistic uncertainty terms are defined in terms of patterns of argument is then proposed. The technique is demonstrated using a prototype computer-based system for predicting the carcinogenic risk due to novel chemical compounds.

sections.text: 1 INTRODUCTION1In the complex and dynamic world in which we live, risk assessment plays an increasingly important role in public and private decision-making and policy-making; decisions based on the possibility of global warming can, for example, have far-reaching financial, environmental and sociological consequences; as well as the inability to persuade a local authority to accept a subjective risk assessment based on a "dangerous" road can have serious and tragic personal consequences; these two examples have been deliberately chosen because they can both be used to illustrate the extreme difficulty of establishing a reliable score for the likelihood of realising a perceived risk. Nevertheless, the potential negative consequences are so great that some meaningful risk characterisation is needed to make a coherent decision on appropriate measures. This paper examines the problem of risk assessment in an area where chemical carcinogenicity plays an essential role, with quantitative risk assessment playing an important role.

In 1991, Britain's Permanent Secretary for the Department of Transport announced that "funds for traffic calming will be judged on casualty savings, not environmental improvements or anxiety relief' (Brown, 1991).

More recently the situation has changed slightly, but the whole issue of the distinction between one person's per­ ceived risk and another's objective (estimate of) risk remains a major source of conflict in many fields (Adams, 1995).
